headline: How to Make Perfect Polenta
description: Creamy polenta is a perfect pairing for all kinds of meats, stews, and sauces. Learn how to make perfect polenta with Chef John's easy, cheesy recipe.

video.description: See a foolproof method for lump-free polenta.
video.name: How to Make Perfect Polenta

name: How to Make Perfect Polenta
recipeIngredient: 0.5 cup freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, plus more for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Bring water and salt to a boil in a large saucepan; pour polenta slowly into boiling water, whisking constantly until there are no lumps.

Reduce heat to low and simmer, whisking often, until polenta starts to thicken, about 5 minutes. Polenta mixture should still be slightly loose. Cover and cook for 30 minutes, whisking every 5 to 6 minutes. When polenta is too thick to whisk, stir with a wooden spoon. Polenta is done when texture is creamy and the individual grains are tender.

Turn off heat and gently stir 2 tablespoons butter into polenta until butter partially melts; mix 1/2 cup Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese into polenta until cheese has melted. Cover and let stand for 5 minutes to thicken.
Stir polenta and transfer to a serving bowl. Top polenta with remaining 1 tablespoon butter and about 1 tablespoon freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese for garnish.

I included all (except for the Parmegianno-Romano) of the recommended ingredients, but 'eye-balled" the amounts according to what I know to be my own and my family's preferences. Instead of the Parmegianno-Romano, I used a hefty amount of Kraft's shredded "Italian Cheese Blend" (we like things "gooey", but we like things that are "budget-friendly" even more). I served it UNDER (rather than as a "side to") this site's "My Special Shrimp Scampi Florentine". We are 4; I adjusted for 6 (for both recipes). Not even any of the Spinach was left once Dinner was done. This is an "even better than GREAT" Polenta recipe. I can't wait to make it again (and again and again and ...) to serve (rather than, for instance, pasta or rice) UNDER so many of my "standards".
